articles.title: Driver.js: Create On-Page Tours, Highlights, and Contextual Help
articles.description: A no-dependency, vanilla JavaScript library for putting together page tours and contextual help systems. The project is a few years old but has just been entirely rewritten and gained numerous enhancements, plus a huge lick of paint. There are lots of examples to check out.
articles.author: Kamran Ahmed

articles.title: Component Party: A Rosetta Stone of UI Library Code Examples
articles.description: A comparison of different frameworks (like React, Vue, Svelte, Angular, Ember, etc.) by way of simple code snippets covering various tasks.
articles.author: Mathieu Schimmerling

articles.title: Prettier 3.0: Now Powered by ES Modules
articles.description: The popular multi-language code formatter gets a big upgrade with a refactoring to ES modules making up the biggest change (though it can still be used as a library via CommonJS). One side effect is Prettier now supports ESM-based plugins and async parsers which means some necessary changes for Prettier plugin developers.
articles.author: Sosuke Suzuki

articles.title: Crockford on Plain Old JavaScript and the DOM
articles.description: Over the years, Douglas has asked us to only use the good parts of JavaScript, to ‚ñ∂Ô∏è stop using JavaScript, and now he suggests abandoning ‚Äúthe libraries‚Äù to instead work with the DOM directly. Lea Verou üê¶ picked up on this story and said this suggestion still isn't very practical for most web apps as of 2023.
articles.author: Douglas Crockford

articles.title: Useful Functions for a (Deno) HTTP Server
articles.description: You could think of HTTP in a functional way with requests going in and responses/results going out. The author explores Deno‚Äôs new Deno.serve function and how both it and the /x/http_fns functions can provide a more functional approach to common HTTP tasks.
articles.author: Jollytoad

articles.title: Testing the Dark Scenarios of a Node.js App
articles.description: Several examples of often overlooked things you should be testing. What happens when a service times out, code is mutating things it shouldn‚Äôt, or you have zombie processes milling around? These are some of the ‚Äòdark scenarios‚Äô it's not too difficult to prepare for.
articles.author: Yoni Goldberg and Raz Luvaton

articles.title: Creating Randomized Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom Patterns
articles.description: Nintendo's new Zelda game uses repeated, geometric patterns as part of its aesthetic. This post looks at how to recreate such motifs with SVG and JavaScript.
articles.author: Paul Hebert

articles.title: MDX Editor: A Rich Markdown Editor React Component
articles.description: A Lexical-powered Markdown editor for React apps that supports code blocks, tables, and more. The live demo shows off most of what you need to see.
articles.author: Petyo Ivanov

articles.title: electron-vite: Next Generation Electron Build Tooling
articles.description: Fish and chips, Bert and Ernie.. some things are just better together, and so it goes with the Electron desktop app framework and the Vite frontend toolkit. There‚Äôs also an Electron Vite Boilerplate app to kick off a new app with.
articles.author: Alex Wei

articles.title: üìä ¬†Vizzu 0.8: A Library for Animated Data Visualizations
articles.description: Making data visualizations is reasonably easy, but animating them is harder. Vizzu steps in to help you create animated data stories and explorations. There are lots of showcases and examples to peruse.
articles.author: Vizzu Inc.

articles.title: üêä ¬†Putout: A Configurable, Babel-Based Linter and Code Transformer
articles.description: Provides typical linting functionality with ESLint and code transformation with Babel, but distinguishes itself by being prepared to make ‚Äúmore drastic code transformations‚Äù than other tools. It‚Äôs not the most popular option but it makes a good case for itself in its thorough README.
articles.author: coderaiser

articles.title: Standardized Audio Context: Cross-Browser Web Audio API Wrapper
articles.description: A side effect-free abstraction over a subset of the Web Audio API that works reliably across all mainstream browsers.
articles.author: Christoph Guttandin

articles.title: Kanel: Generate TypeScript Types from Postgres
articles.description: It works by inspecting a live database and outputs code you can add to a TypeScript project and use with something like Knex ‚Äì GitHub repo.
articles.author: Kristian Dupont

articles.title: donut.js: donut.c, But in JavaScript
articles.description: donut.c, dating from 2006, is a donut-shaped C program that, when run, animates a spinning ASCII text donut on the screen. Here‚Äôs a fresh and hot JavaScript variant!
articles.author: Evan Zhou

articles.description: Ember 5.1 ‚Äì The ambitious JS framework that'll never give up takes a big step into the TypeScript world with stable TypeScript support and types-a-plenty.
p5.js 1.7 ‚Äì Processing-inspired JavaScript library for creative coding. v1.7 introduces WebGL 2 and frame buffer support.
Prisma 5.0 ‚Äì A popular ORM for Node.js and TypeScript. 5.0 boasts significant performance improvements.
typescript-eslint 6.0
obj?.prop = value; The optional chaining assignment proposal advanced to stage 1 at TC39 this week. (Explanatory slidedeck.)

Popular YouTube channel Fireship explains ‚ñ∂Ô∏è htmx in 100 seconds ‚Äì well timed, since htmx is seeing a huge amount of fresh interest. And if you're wondering who the mastermind behind Fireship is, Honeypot has put up ‚ñ∂Ô∏è a short documentary about him.

The folks at Sandworm have shared a look at the state of the npm registry including lots of trivia, history, and stats on how many packages there are, as well as the most commonly used keywords in packages.

Google shares a case study on performance of scroll-driven animations using its new browser based API versus 'classical JavaScript techniques.' Unsurprisingly it's much faster running away from the main thread, and the spec remains in draft for now.
npm will now check the linked source commit and repo when you view a package's provenance information on npmjs.com and warn you when said provenance cannot be established.
GitHub is rolling out a beta of passwordless, passkey based authentication on GitHub‚Ä§com.

articles.title: Exploring Modern Alternatives to vh/vw Units
articles.description: Ahmad brings us up to speed on the new(ish) small, large, and dynamic viewport units in CSS (e.g. svh, lvh, and dvh) and how they work across various mobile browsers. As ever, there are plenty of visuals to convey the points being made. Getting mobile page height right has long been tricky, but these new units make things more manageable and browser support is good too, which makes a nice change.
articles.author: Ahmad Shadeed

articles.title: <The Case Against Self-Closing Tags in HTML />
articles.description: /> is sometimes ignored, and sometimes it isn‚Äôt‚Ä¶ should we still be writing this? Should Prettier still be enforcing this? Does it matter? Jake shares his stance on a technique whose origin goes back more than 20 years.
articles.author: Jake Archibald

articles.title: ‚ñ∂¬†¬†Modern CSS Layout is Awesome
articles.description: A ~45-minute talk that will tell you what you need to know about modern approaches to CSS layout, covering some of the new features at our disposal and how to use them.
articles.author: Michelle Barker

articles.title: WCAG 2.2: Quick and Simplified
articles.description: With a new version of the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines on the cusp of becoming a standard, here‚Äôs a brief, simplified look at the nine new requirements.
articles.author: Mike Gower

articles.title: Coding Randomized 'Tears of the Kingdom' Zelda Patterns
articles.description: The new Zelda game (which I‚Äôm really enjoying btw ‚Äî but I have a Nintendo newsletter for that) uses repeated, geometric patterns to build a cohesive aesthetic throughout the world. Paul looks at how to recreate this motif with code. A fun little SVG experiment, and a pen-plotting robot even gets involved.
articles.author: Paul Hebert

articles.title: Offset Parent and Stacking Context: Positioning Elements in All Three Dimensions
articles.description: How you can use the offset parent and stacking context to position elements in all three dimensions, and how to debug them.
articles.author: Kilian Valkhof

articles.title: Permission
articles.description: It‚Äôs generally accepted that our sites are crawled so people can find them via search, but are we ok with our sites being crawled to help train an LLM? In the evolving era of AI, Jeremy notes: ‚ÄúWe can rescind our invitation to Google‚Äù.
articles.author: Jeremy Keith

articles.title: What‚Äôs the Best Font? See How You and Others Perceive Different Types
articles.description: A neat interactive article that runs through the unique characteristics of a few fonts and shares how these differences are perceived.
articles.author: Kumar, Fowler, Shapiro (The Washington Post)

articles.title: SVG Hub: 70+ Custom-Color Elements Ready to Paste Into Your¬†Project
articles.description: A unique set of graphics in SVG format consisting of squiggles, scribbles, and other unusual shapes ‚Äî and you can live-edit the colors on the page to test out various palettes.
articles.author: Daniel Cranney

articles.title: Tailkits: A Directory of Tailwind CSS Templates, Components, and¬†More
articles.description: Currently includes more than 250 products, and you can easily filter by free or paid and select by category (dashboards, landing pages, e-commerce, portfolios, etc).
articles.author: Tailkits

articles.title: Prettier 3.0 Released
articles.description: The latest version of the popular code formatter (which isn‚Äôt just for JavaScript, it tackles CSS, JSX, Markdown, and numerous templating formats too) is here.
articles.author: Sosuke Suzuki

articles.title: Proportio: An Interactive Tool to Create Proportional Scales
articles.description: Similar to other type scale tools, but this one is much more complete, allowing you to create proportional scales for type, shapes, components, and even containers. Lots to fiddle around with here!
articles.author: nate baldwin

articles.title: MathLive: A Web Component for Math Input
articles.description: A web component that provides an interface for editing formulas. It supports hundreds of LaTeX commands and uses LaTeX-style typesetting to keep things looking slick. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Arno Gourdol

articles.title: comiCSS: The ABCs of CSS
articles.description: Each letter of the alphabet here is drawn with CSS and showcases one CSS property/value - like A for aspect-ratio. There‚Äôs a live demo version here too.
articles.author: Alvaro Montoro

articles.description: Chris Coyier thinks about how features from Sass have gradually ended up in CSS proper. Thanks Sass and SCSS.
Aaron Francis looks at how you can 'write' PHP on the frontend using Laravel Livewire.
Manueo Matuzoviƒá is seeking submissions for this year's HTMHell Advent Calendar.
Where you at? No, Kelly Rowland couldn't have used Excel's =HYPERLINK() function to message Nelly. Apparently.
GitHub has added support for managing projects via GitHub Projects to its CLI tool.
